title: Cat. 82  Bowl or Cup, mid-1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Bowl or Cup  
Mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman, probably Italy  
Glass, cast; h. 4 cm (1 5/8 in.); diam. 8.7 cm (3 3/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1947.883

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Opaque white glass with some pinprick bubbles. Cast and rotary polished, short outsplayed rim, the edge rounded by grinding, bends down and inward to form a short, convex-profile collar above a deep convex body on a short, flared base ring. The foot has a flat depression on its underside, the edge rounded by reheating and somewhat uneven. For a zoomable image, see fig. 82.1.

The piece is intact with light-brown weathering product overall with some pitting, irregular horizontal areas appear scraped and cleaned; weathering product is worn away. Rough parallel grinding marks from cleaning are on the interior. A small strain crack is at the carination above the body on the interior.

This shape was extremely popular and was made in a variety of sizes and profiles; for additional remarks see the Art Institute’s translucent deep-blue glass example (cat. 81) and the example in the mosaic glass technique (cat. 83).  
Sidney Goldstein
